city: Marinth Vell, the Tideglass Metropolis, rises on piles and causeways over the nine estuarine inlets that form the Harbor of Nine Mouths along the Sunken Pearl coast. Its skyline glows with living towers of blue-green tideglass that shimmer and hum when the moon draws the tide. The city was founded 412 years ago by desert refugees from Khelar, led by the tidal oracle Myr Sal, who read the river and storm as if they were books; guided to the coast, they survived their first winter by melting black sand and mangrove resin in a thunder-wracked caldera to birth a beacon of singing glass that lured shoals and sailors alike to safe water. From that first beacon, Marinth Vell seeded a craft, a faith, and a state. The city is braced by chain-gates across each inlet, and its nine districts—Spillward, Prism Quay, Brinemarket, Chainmouth, Piles' End, Salt Gate, Lamplands, Glassward, and Archive Crown—are stitched by bridges, ferry-ropes, and glimmering walkways that flex with the tide. Economy and culture pivot on the art of tideglass: living glass coaxed to grow like coral with songs and resin, set with storm-born fulgurites, and hardened with salt rites. Fishers and kelp-harvesters set out at dawn past the Glassreef Shoals, while caravans arrive through the Salt Gate bearing slabs from the Sere Flats and obsidian grit from the Shattercoast Cliffs for the kilns of Prism Quay. The Brine Archive carves law and ledger into slabs of salt and resin, while the Conclave of Prismancers wraps memory and light into lenses that can be replayed like music. Governance is officially a Trium of tide-lords—the Harbormistress (currently Nerey Alis), the Archivist-Talon (Var Sile), and the Speaker of Piles (Jorden Tatch)—but real power eddies among guilds and houses: the Glassworkers' Concord, the Dockers' Syndicate, House Saltvein, the River Wardens, and the Faith of Azerene, the Censered Tide. Marinth Vell depends on salt from the Sere Flats, resin from the Elder Mangrove of Iska, and storms above the Storm-Kiln Caldera to keep its tideglass craft alive; each is controlled or contested by a different faction, creating a lattice of obligation. Festivals mark the city's rhythm: the Nine Mouths Unfettered when the chain-gates are lifted together to draw the sea's favor; the Glass Blossom when a new tower is seeded in the Nursery; and Azerene's Candles when shells filled with oil and prayers are set adrift. Threats whisper beneath prosperity: pirates skirting the Veiled Current; the leviathan Uln, said to sleep under the shoals; salt tariffs that can starve the poor; and old Khelaran ghosts who haunt mirrors when storms make the tideglass sing. Marinth Vell is a city that remembers in salt and glass, and it owes its survival to the sea it tries to name.

surroundings.name: Storm-Kiln Caldera
surroundings.distance: half a day upriver by barge then a climb inland
surroundings.description: A lightning-split basin filled with mineral-rich pools and fused spires where storms regularly ground themselves. The first tideglass was born here, and still the greatest runs are grown when thunder steps down the ridges.
surroundings.history: Once a hermitage for fulgurite mystics who believed fire taught sand to remember, the caldera became the beating heart of Marinth Vell's industry. Control of its furnaces has changed hands five times in a century, each transfer marked by a new crack in the highest spire.
surroundings.legends: It is whispered the gods hammered a piece of night into the caldera and left it as the Heartshard; oaths spoken within earshot of a strike cannot be unmade without the speaker coughing up glass. Some claim Myr Sal hid her final breath here to keep storms friendly to the city.
surroundings.resources: Storm energy, fulgurites, volcanic glass, rare salts baked in lightning pools
surroundings.dangers: Sudden ground-fire, fulgar sprites drawn to metal, glass fume sickness, rival saboteurs during storm runs
surroundings.dependencies: The Glassworkers' Concord and Conclave of Prismancers require regular storm access to grow and tune tideglass; House Saltvein supplies brine to temper it.

surroundings.name: Saltstep Marsh
surroundings.description: A broad, breathing marsh that lifts and lowers with the tide, dotted with reed-thatch stilt homes, eel gardens, and bone walkways. Fireflies and lanterns make constellations on water at dusk.
surroundings.history: Home to the Piledwellers long before the city's rise, the marsh gave labor, food, and pathways. The Speaker of Piles is still elected from these villages in theory, but in practice coin and cargo determine the vote.
surroundings.legends: The Bone Bridge is said to be grown from the ribs of a leviathan who died here; if you leave a lantern at its midpoint, it lights a path to one mistake you can still fix. Marsh-wives whisper to knot tides into charms.
surroundings.resources: Eels, reeds, marsh herbs, mangrove resin collectors
surroundings.dangers: Bog-suck, night egrets that lure with mimicry, malaria-like marsh fever called green blister
surroundings.dependencies: Marinth Vell relies on the marsh for food and resin runners; the Piledwellers rely on city markets for tools and salt.

surroundings.name: Glassreef Shoals
surroundings.distance: one hour by sail from the outer chains
surroundings.description: A glittering maze of living tideglass creeping over rock and coral, pulsing with light like breath. At night, the shoals shimmer with currents, a map the old pilots can read.
surroundings.history: The Reefkeepers learned to harvest plumes without cracking root structures, after a generation of overcutting caused a storm-wrath that lamed the fleet.
surroundings.legends: The Reef-Mother sings a lullaby that guides the leviathan Uln to sleep. Should the reef be shattered, Uln wakes and bellows a tide that drowns the nine districts. Sailors claim the Tenth Mouth opens in the reef for traitors.
surroundings.resources: Pearls, glass-polyp seeds, fish, phosphor lichen
surroundings.dangers: Shards underfoot, razor eels that nest in facets, pirate cut-throughs in fog
surroundings.dependencies: Reef health determines harvest quotas for tideglass seeds; the Faith of Azerene enforces taboos around spawning seasons.
related_factions: Faith of Azerene, the Censered Tide

surroundings.name: Silted Basilica
surroundings.distance: beneath the third inlet at low tide
surroundings.description: An ancient pearl-inlaid cathedral whose nave tilts beneath the tide. Columns arise like tusks from silt, with an organ of shell that groans in storms.
surroundings.history: Scholars argue it predates Marinth Vell by centuries, possibly the heart of a drowned faith that worshiped memory as a tide. Attempts to dredge it fully have failed as silt returns overnight as if poured by unseen hands.
surroundings.legends: The bell of the Basilica rings only for treason; the Nacre Crown sleeps in a reliquary guarded by a choir of bubbles that steal breath. A saint called the Pearl-Warder bartered her bones to anchor this coast.
surroundings.resources: Ancient reliquaries, pearlescent mosaics, spirit-kelp used by apothecaries
surroundings.dangers: Silt-surge that buries divers, echo-sickness from the shell organ, revenant parishioners that ask for confessions you never made
surroundings.dependencies: The Brine Archive funds careful exploration; the League of Lanterns maps safe currents for sanctioned dives.
related_factions: Faith of Azerene, the Censered Tide

surroundings.name: Shattercoast Cliffs
surroundings.distance: two days down the coast by cart and sail
surroundings.description: A series of serrated cliffs that shed obsidian sand like dark waterfalls into pounding surf. Wind knives shriek through galleries carved by ages.
surroundings.history: Khelaran exile families staked claims here after the city's founding; the cliffs provided sand for the first century of expansion until quotas were imposed.
surroundings.legends: Shardwights mimic you a heartbeat behind your movements; if they ever catch up, you are replaced and only mirrors will tell truth. A Mirror-King walks here in a storm-crown, hunting those who swore to forget him in Khelar.
surroundings.resources: Obsidian sand, cutting glass, wind-hollowed stones used for resonance in instruments
surroundings.dangers: Rockfalls, mirage gashes, shardwight reflections that lure climbers
surroundings.dependencies: The Glassworkers need regulated sand loads; River Wardens patrol for smugglers taking sand beyond quota.

surroundings.name: Elder Mangrove of Iska
surroundings.type: primeval mangrove titan and resin forest
surroundings.distance: up the delta forks beyond the marsh
surroundings.description: A labyrinth of roots as big as fortresses, braided over channels that can swallow caravans. The central trunk is said to be as wide as a plaza, with resin drops that glow faintly.
surroundings.history: Contracts and taboos bind cutters, for deep cuts loosen the delta's grip and flood the marsh. The Knotted Wives keep book of knots that promise storms or calm.
surroundings.legends: Iska is a sleeping titan; if woken in anger, she will stand and walk, carrying the delta into the sea and leaving Marinth Vell high and dry on broken piles. Resin whispers if heated with the right song, telling you what the tree has seen.
surroundings.resources: Resin for tideglass binding, hardwood, rare bark with medicinal uses
surroundings.dangers: Sinking channels, territorial crocodiles, resin ghosts that stick to the lungs
surroundings.dependencies: The Glassblossom Nursery requires fresh resin; the Faith of Azerene sanctions the Knotted Wives' rites; House Saltvein pays to move resin along their brine canals.
related_factions: Faith of Azerene, the Censered Tide

surroundings.name: The Veiled Current
surroundings.distance: runs beneath the outer shelf from the shoals to distant archipelagoes
surroundings.description: An invisible river under the sea, its flow can be found by watching phosphor veils peel and fold like curtains. Only pilots trained by scent and song can ride it without vanishing.
surroundings.history: Long denied by officials, the Current is now grudgingly charted. The Reefkeepers mark its entrances subtly to steer traffic away from spawning beds.
surroundings.legends: The Current is said to be Azerene's own hair, and knots in it become storms. Uln's Lullaby runs through it, and those who hum along return home no matter how far they travel.
surroundings.resources: Fast travel, hidden routes, contraband channels
surroundings.dangers: Sudden shear that flips hulls, veil eels that numb limbs, pirate ambuscades
surroundings.dependencies: The League of Lanterns controls coded lantern signals to enter safely; River Wardens post decoy beacons to catch smugglers.

surroundings.name: Sere Flats
surroundings.distance: three days inland by the White Thread road
surroundings.description: Blinding salt pans stepped like amphitheaters around dried lakes, with caravans moving in files like ants across white mirrors.
surroundings.history: House Saltvein grew powerful purchasing claim-rights and fortifying brine canals, setting tariffs that grew fortunes and riots in turn.
surroundings.legends: Salt Saints calcify curses and sell them as relics. On certain nights a Glass Camel walks the flats; if it kneels before you, your debts pool and harden into salt cubes you can carry but cannot eat.
surroundings.resources: Salt slabs, brine, candied limes from oasis fringe
surroundings.dangers: Salt storms that flense skin, mirage brigands, cracked pans that swallow carts
surroundings.dependencies: Marinth Vell's Brine Archive and preservation trades need steady salt; Dockers rely on predictable tariffs to keep wages fair.

buildings.name: Beacon of Myr Sal (Tideglass Spire)
buildings.description: A tapering spire of tideglass whose skin ripples with sea-hued light. Its cap houses prisms that turn storms into song, relayed across the harbor and marsh.
buildings.history: Grown from the first seed cast by Myr Sal herself, the spire has weathered four collapses and regrowths, incorporating shards from each into its core.
buildings.functions: Navigation beacon, storm-choir chamber, citywide signal relay, ceremonial focus for the Glass Blossom festival
buildings.legends: Some believe the Heartshard sleeps in its root; when the spire keens in a clear sky, a great lie has been told in the city.
buildings.dependencies: Requires resin from Iska, fulgurites from the caldera, and precise song-etchings maintained by the Conclave.
buildings.controlled_by: Conclave of Prismancers and Faith of Azerene jointly by uneasy concordat
buildings.rival_claims: Glassworkers' Concord argues for sole stewardship; Dockers' Syndicate demands labor shares on maintenance climbs.

buildings.name: The Brine Archive
buildings.description: A complex of stacked salt rooms sealed with amber and kept at precise humidity where ledgers, laws, and oaths are etched into brined slabs.
buildings.history: Founded by the Order of Brine-Scribes to resist fire, moth, and forgery, the Archive survived the Great Harbor Fire chiefly because it refused to burn.
buildings.functions: Record-keeping, oath witnessing, map vaults, tax rolls, library of salt-steles
buildings.legends: It is said the Archive keeps a room of true names; anyone who enters without leave leaves without their memory of why.
buildings.dependencies: Salt slabs from Sere Flats, resin from Iska to seal edges, lamp crews from the League of Lanterns
buildings.rival_claims: Conclave of Prismancers pushes for an Illuminary Annex to encode memory in light; House Saltvein seeks preferential access to tariff logs.

buildings.name: Harbor of Nine Mouths
buildings.description: Nine inlets bridged by keep-houses of tideglass and stone. Each inlet is guarded by a sea-chain winched up at the onset of storms or pirate raids.
buildings.history: Built over three generations, the chain-gates were inspired by river booms upriver. The Tenth Mouth is a whispered term for hidden channels pirates use.
buildings.functions: Port access control, customs, fish markets, pilot berths, chain-house garrisons
buildings.legends: When all nine chains lift in unison, it is said Azerene opens her eyes and looks kindly on the city for a day and a night.
buildings.dependencies: Iron from inland, oil from marsh seeds, trained wardens, lamp signals
buildings.rival_claims: House Saltvein wants tariff leniency on its brine barges; Reefkeepers demand closures during spawn.

buildings.name: Windward Bastion
buildings.description: A squat, many-angled fort with tempest-catchers, ballistae, and chain-route winches, built to anchor the outer defense and secure the Veiled Current's entrance.
buildings.history: Constructed after the Corsair Year, when pirates stealthed in fog and sacked the Lamplands. The bastion's captaincy is the most fought-over post in the Wardens.
buildings.functions: Defense, patrol mustering, customs seizure, storm signal relay
buildings.legends: St. Brinehand's glove is said to be bricked into the keel-room; those who touch it cannot be bribed for a day.
buildings.dependencies: Armory iron, stormglass panes for visibility, Warden crews, Prismancer-sighted lenses
buildings.rival_claims: League of Lanterns wants a watch niche for covert signaling; Dockers want safer muster stairs for emergency evacuations.

buildings.name: The Prism Bazaar
buildings.description: A covered market threaded with refracting canopies that split light into color-rivers; stalls shift places as the canopies turn.
buildings.history: Raised by the Glassworkers with a grant from the Conclave to demonstrate peaceful uses of illusion; became the city's preferred site for oaths and proposals.
buildings.functions: Trade hub for glass goods, rare salts, lenses, festival venue, public assemblies
buildings.legends: If you confess under a full spectrum, your shadow will no longer lie for you; lovers test themselves here.
buildings.dependencies: Conclave lens-tenders, Guild labor, lantern crews, peddler dues
buildings.rival_claims: Order of Brine-Scribes demands a fixed stall for legal postings; Dockers push for capped rents.

buildings.name: Amber Vaults
buildings.description: Resin-lined vault cavities that smell of pine and lemons, filled with crates, coins, and ambered documents. Bees kept within produce wax used to seal tariffs.
buildings.history: Founded after the Great Ledger Flood, when a spring burst beneath the old treasury. Amber saved more from rot than paper ever did.
buildings.functions: Tariff collection, storage, coin striking in amber-sealed molds, collateral holding
buildings.legends: A queen bee of legend nests in the oldest vault; she whispers the true weight of any debt to those who sleep there.
buildings.dependencies: Resin supply from Iska, coin blanks, scribe crews, guards from House Saltvein's hirelings
buildings.controlled_by: Trium oversight with House Saltvein contracts
buildings.rival_claims: Dockers' Syndicate wants wage escrow transparency; League of Lanterns seeks an audit of missing lantern dues.

buildings.name: Court of Echoing Shells
buildings.description: A long, low hall hung with great polished shells that keen or hush depending on truth. Nacre-masked judges preside in soft sandals to avoid offense.
buildings.history: Erected under the first concordat with the Faith of Azerene, whose priests trained the shell choir to hear perjury.
buildings.legends: A liar can bribe every judge but never the shells; once they keen for you, they will keen at your whisper for all your years.
buildings.dependencies: Shell harvest rites, priest-tuners, scribes, public attendance for legitimacy
buildings.controlled_by: Faith of Azerene and Order of Brine-Scribes in joint service
buildings.rival_claims: Conclave insists on a lens of record; House Saltvein wants closed hearings in tariff disputes.

buildings.name: Glassblossom Nursery
buildings.description: Pools and vats where glass-polyp seeds are coaxed to bud and branch with song, heat, and careful resin dosing; floors are sprung to absorb tremors.
buildings.history: Spawned from the first harvest of the Reefkeepers after the Storm-Wrath Quota; it became the training ground for a generation of Glasswrights.
buildings.functions: Seed propagation, architectural component growth, instrument crafting
buildings.legends: A seed once sang back a name that no one had spoken in two centuries; three witnesses forgot what names were for a day.
buildings.dependencies: Resin from Iska, polyp seeds from Glassreef Shoals, storm-heat from Caldera runs
buildings.rival_claims: Reefkeepers demand veto power over seed take; Conclave wants access to sing unusual chords.

buildings.name: Dockers' House of Weights
buildings.description: A stout hall where weights and measures are calibrated on a slate of meteoric iron; walls are gouged with tally-marks of past strikes.
buildings.history: Built by pooled wages after a scandal of shaved scales nearly starved the fishers. It is a shrine to fair dealing and quick tempers.
buildings.functions: Instrument calibration, wage arbitration, strike musters, feast hall
buildings.legends: Any scale balanced here will return to balance within a year—if not by coin, then by fate.
buildings.dependencies: Neutral inspectors, iron-slate maintenance, lantern crews for night shifts
buildings.rival_claims: House Saltvein disputes its right to certify brine weights; Trium seeks to install a state inspector.

buildings.name: Salt Gate Manse
buildings.type: merchant house complex and salt depot
buildings.description: A fortified compound with brine canals running under its floors, vault doors carved in salt motifs, and a gate that tastes of the sea when the wind turns.
buildings.history: Expanded with every tariff war won. Its banqueting hall is paved with discarded salt seals of debt paid and unpaid.
buildings.functions: Salt storage, caravan coordination, contract halls, private guard barracks
buildings.legends: If you swear a false purity oath under its lintel, your sweat turns brackish for seven days and all can taste your lie.
buildings.dependencies: Salt caravans from Sere Flats, private guards, dock berths, bribe circuits
buildings.rival_claims: Dockers demand public berths freed from private lock; League of Lanterns alleges hidden tunnels to the Veiled Current.

politics.name: Glassworkers' Concord
politics.leadership: Master Glasswright Alaya of the Four Kilns
politics.assets: Kilns at Prism Quay, Glassblossom Nursery, shares in the Beacon and market stalls at the Prism Bazaar
politics.methods: Apprenticeship control, seed quotas, price cartels, strike threats that halt tower maintenance
politics.goals: Maintain control over tideglass craft, secure storm access at the caldera, win sole stewardship of the Beacon
politics.rivals: Conclave of Prismancers, House Saltvein, Reefkeepers' Lodge
politics.allies: Dockers' Syndicate (on labor), Order of Brine-Scribes (on documentation)
politics.base: Guildhall in Glassward adjacent to the Nursery
politics.history: Formed after the Storm-Wrath Quota to prevent overharvest and standardize song-etching. They have broken three embargoes with emergency repairs during crises to prove civic virtue.
politics.conflicts: Ongoing dispute with the Conclave over who 'tunes' citywide glass; sand quotas at the Shattercoast; Reefkeepers' restrictions on seed take
politics.dependencies: Resin from Iska, sand from Shattercoast, storm runs at the caldera
politics.legends: They keep a shard that sings only when a future arch collapses; some Masters sleep with it under the pillow to dream of faults.

politics.name: Conclave of Prismancers
politics.assets: Lens vaults, storm-choirs, a private dome in the Beacon, Illuminary laboratories
politics.methods: Light-bending rites, memory-capture, civic illusions for signaling and celebrations, subtle surveillance by color drift
politics.goals: Replace salt steles with light archives, maintain joint control of the Beacon, expand research into reef-song and Uln's Lullaby
politics.rivals: Order of Brine-Scribes, Faith of Azerene (over doctrine), Glassworkers' Concord
politics.allies: Trium technocrats, portions of the League of Lanterns
politics.base: The Prismarium, a cluster of domes in Prism Quay
politics.history: Began as a circle of signalers then embraced theory after decoding refraction in tideglass. Their early 'memory orbs' caused a scandal when a council session was replayed in the Bazaar.
politics.conflicts: Ethical oversight on memory-capture, reef-taboo breaches, access to the Storm-Kiln Caldera during Faith holidays
politics.dependencies: A steady flow of lenses, storm access, test subjects from willing guilds
politics.legends: They believe the city itself is an instrument tuned to a forgotten chord; if played, it will open a Tenth Mouth inland.

politics.name: Order of Brine-Scribes
politics.assets: The Brine Archive, seal presses, cadre of oath-witnesses, salt stele caravans
politics.methods: Salt-etch law, oath codexes, audit trails, training of neutral recorders
politics.goals: Preserve civic memory immune to sorcery, guard true names, maintain legal supremacy over contracts
politics.rivals: Conclave of Prismancers, House Saltvein (tariffs), League of Lanterns (unofficial ledgers)
politics.allies: Faith of Azerene (oath doctrine), Trium reformers
politics.history: Rose to prominence after repeated fires and floods proved salt truer than ink. They broke a dock blockade by distributing food via 'oath kitchens' that required no coin.
politics.conflicts: Refusal to recognize light-record as legal proof, salt shortages during drought years, accusations of name-hoarding
politics.dependencies: Salt from Sere Flats, resin seals, civic trust
politics.legends: They keep a Name-Room whispered to be dangerous; even the Trium cannot enter without losing something remembered.

politics.name: Dockers' Syndicate
politics.assets: House of Weights, strike coffers, chainhouse crews, cargo schedules
politics.methods: Strike and slowdown, certification of fair weights, mass assemblies at the Bazaar
politics.goals: Fair tariffs for laborers, safer chainhouse protocols, a public seat on the Trium
politics.rivals: House Saltvein, River Wardens' brass (on safety enforcement), certain smugglers
politics.allies: Glassworkers' Concord (when wages align), League of Lanterns (signal solidarity)
politics.history: Forged in scarcity and heated by tragedy when thirteen dockers drowned in a chainjam. They celebrated the first 'Weighing Day' to reset rigged scales citywide.
politics.conflicts: Tariff skirmishes with Saltvein, jurisdiction fights with Wardens, infiltration attempts by corsair agents
politics.dependencies: Predictable tariff schedules, safe equipment, lamp crews
politics.legends: Their meteoric iron slate is said to straighten bent men; those who cheat on it find their backs ache for a season.

politics.name: River Wardens
politics.assets: Windward Bastion, chainhouses, patrol boats with storm-rigs, armories
politics.methods: Patrol, interdiction, chain-lift drills, controlled fireships
politics.goals: Secure harbor, suppress smuggling on the Veiled Current, maintain a monopoly on legitimate force
politics.rivals: Dockers' Syndicate (over safety protocols), League of Lanterns (secret routes), corsair flotillas
politics.allies: Trium traditionalists, Faith of Azerene (ceremonial guard), Reefkeepers (spawn patrols)
politics.history: Elevated from watch to disciplined force after the Corsair Year; ever since, they have cultivated storm discipline with drills under lightning.
politics.conflicts: Budget fights with the Trium, allegations of brutality in the Lamplands, covert power plays for the Bastion's captaincy
politics.dependencies: Funding from tariffs, skilled pilots, stormglass maintenance
politics.legends: Wardens swear by Brinehand's glove; those who break oath under it find their hands salt-burned in their sleep.

politics.name: House Saltvein
politics.assets: Salt Gate Manse, brine canals, caravan guards, bonded warehouses in the Amber Vaults
politics.methods: Tariff manipulation, loan-for-salt collateral, patronage of festivals, private security
politics.goals: Secure salt monopoly, reduce labor influence on customs, seat a Saltvein on the Trium
politics.rivals: Dockers' Syndicate, Order of Brine-Scribes, portions of the Trium
politics.allies: Certain River Wardens commanders, desert caravan magnates, compliant scribes
politics.history: Rose from desert traders to coastal magnates through relentless acquisition of salt rights. Credited with saving the city during the Famine Flood by releasing reserve brine to preserve stores.
politics.conflicts: Accused of creating artificial shortages, secret tunnels to the Veiled Current, clandestine funding of dock-boss rivals
politics.dependencies: Sere Flats production, stable law to enforce contracts, reliable guards
politics.legends: The manse lintel oath makes sweat taste brackish for liars; some claim Sel Var never sweats.

politics.name: Faith of Azerene, the Censered Tide
politics.assets: Court of Echoing Shells, censer barges, shell choirs, shrine network through the marsh
politics.methods: Oath witnessing, taboos on harvest, processions, blessings for storm and memory
politics.goals: Keep balance with sea and reef, bind the city to its vows, check arcane overreach
politics.rivals: Conclave of Prismancers (doctrine and authority), unscrupulous Reef-harvesters, certain Trium members
politics.allies: Order of Brine-Scribes, Reefkeepers' Lodge, Piledwellers' Assembly
politics.history: Unified scattered marsh cults under a rite that burns brine in shell censers. Their shells keen for lies and hush for truth, and the city has leaned on them ever since.
politics.conflicts: Conclave's push for light-record supplanting oaths, harvest disputes at Glassreef, internal schisms over whether Azerene is sea or memory first
politics.dependencies: Shell supply, public trust, cooperation from guilds for taboos
politics.legends: Priests can smell betrayal as ozone before a storm; Azerene once blinked and a flood receded in an eye's breadth.

politics.name: Reefkeepers' Lodge
politics.leadership: Reef-Mistress Pana of the Three Cuts
politics.assets: Pilot charts, reef nurseries, signal huts on outer rocks
politics.methods: Harvest quotas, pilot licensing, sabotage of poachers, charm-laying in spawning beds
politics.goals: Preserve the Glassreef, maintain pilot authority, prevent awakening of Uln
politics.rivals: Glassworkers (excess seed demands), pirate syndicates, impatient Trium merchants
politics.allies: Faith of Azerene, River Wardens (on spawn patrols), League of Lanterns (on signals)
politics.base: Outer reef huts and a lodge at Prism Quay
politics.history: Formed after the Storm-Wrath, when an overcut harvest brought three weeks of razor squalls. They cut their right palms together to remember the cost.
politics.conflicts: Smuggler routes through spawning beds, political pressure to raise quotas, sabotage accusations from injured harvesters
politics.dependencies: Seasonal cycles, clean waters, respect from pilots and guilds
politics.legends: They say the Reef-Mother will grow a bridge to the city if ever it is truly besieged—if the city has kept faith.

politics.name: League of Lanterns
politics.leadership: First Lantern Orel of the Veils
politics.assets: Lantern towers, coded signal books, a network of oil stores, silent boats
politics.methods: Signal codes, courier service, rumor brokerage, selective blackouts to screen operations
politics.goals: Keep light on for those who pay and those who deserve, remain indispensable to every faction's plans
politics.rivals: River Wardens (over control of beacons), House Saltvein (over tariff-funded lantern dues), certain smugglers
politics.allies: Dockers' Syndicate, Conclave (for lens-craft), Order of Brine-Scribes (for public notices)
politics.base: Lamplands with outposts at every inlet
politics.history: Began as a night watch and grew into a citywide nerve, mapping shadow and glow. In the Corsair Year, their decoy lights sank three ships.
politics.conflicts: Accusations of selling routes, withholding light during strikes, double-coding messages for profit
politics.dependencies: Oil supply, public trust, neutrality myth
politics.legends: Their oldest lantern never goes out; if it does, the city's memory will spill like oil over stone.

politics.name: Piledwellers' Assembly
politics.leadership: Speaker Jorden Tatch (also the Trium's Speaker of Piles)
politics.assets: Community granaries, ferry rights, marsh schoolhouses, knot-books
politics.methods: Village votes, knot-law (binding charms used as contracts), ferry blockades
politics.goals: Protect marsh rights, keep resin quotas fair, ensure floodworks favor stilt-villages
politics.rivals: Trium urbanists, House Saltvein surveyors, unscrupulous resin-cutters
politics.history: Formalized after early exploitation by city taxmen who could not read marsh knots. Their ferry blockades have ended more disputes than court edicts.
politics.conflicts: Encroachment by city piles into fishing grounds, resin tax hikes, education battles over knot-law recognition
politics.dependencies: Healthy marsh, fair ferry tolls, recognition by city courts
politics.legends: An Assembly knot tied by the Knotted Wives can hold back a spring flood—if every villager sings the tying song.
